unnormalised: Okay, so you know how everyone's obsessed with fancy degrees and all that jazz? I mean, it's true, a piece of paper saying "B.A." or "M.Sc." after your name does open doors. But let's be real, the real story is in the details, right? What exactly did you achieve during those years? Did you just attend classes and mug up notes, or did you actually, you know, *do* something?
normalised: Okay, so you know how everyone is obsessed with fancy degrees and all that jazz? I mean, it's true, a piece of paper saying "B-A" or "M-S-C" after your name does open doors. But let's be real, the real story is in the details, right? What exactly did you achieve during those years? Did you just attend classes and mug up notes, or did you actually, you know, do something?

unnormalised: See, nowadays, simply holding a "B.Tech" from some random college isn’t enough. Everyone and their ajji seems to have one! It’s about what sets you apart. Did you lead a project? Did you win any awards? Did you actually learn the stuff they taught you? The devil, as they say, is in the transcripts and extracurriculars, my friend.

unnormalised: My cousin, Priya, she just finished her "MBA" from IIM Ahmedabad. Sounds impressive, right? But then I asked her what she actually *did* there. Turns out, she was the president of the marketing club and organized a massive national-level competition! That's way more interesting than just saying you have an MBA.

unnormalised: And it's not just about formal degrees. Think about all the online courses and certifications people are doing now. "Google Data Analytics Professional Certificate" or a "Coursera specialization in AI" – these things can be seriously valuable, especially if you can show how you used that knowledge in a real-world project. My friend, Rakesh, did the "Harvard CS50" course online and built a whole app based on what he learnt!

My friend, Rakesh, did the "Harvard C-S fifty" course online and built a whole app based on what he learned!

unnormalised: It’s the same with school too, no? Scoring a "98%" in the ICSE exams is great, but did you participate in the science exhibition? Did you win the debate competition? These things show that you're not just a bookworm, but someone who can actually apply their knowledge and think on their feet. Remember that time I won the "All India Essay Writing Competition" back in class 10th? I still brag about that!

unnormalised: When you’re applying for a job, or even just networking, don't just rattle off a list of degrees. Tell a story! Explain what you learned, what you achieved, and how it made you a better person. Did you manage a team while working towards that "PhD"? Talk about it!
normalised: When you're applying for a job, or even just networking, don't just rattle off a list of degrees. Tell a story! Explain what you learned, what you achieved, and how it made you a better person. Did you manage a team while working towards that "P-h-D"? Talk about it!

unnormalised: For example, I was part of the "IEEE Robotics and Automation Society Student Branch" during my engineering. We built a freaking robot that could solve a maze! That's a much more compelling story than just saying I have a "BE" in Mechanical Engineering. It shows initiative, teamwork, and problem-solving skills.

That's a much more compelling story than just saying I have a "B-E" in Mechanical Engineering. It shows initiative, teamwork, and problem-solving skills.

unnormalised: And don’t forget to highlight any scholarships or awards you received. A "National Talent Search Examination" scholarship? A "President's Gold Medal" for academic excellence? These are definitely worth mentioning. They demonstrate that you were recognized for your hard work and talent. I got the "Best Student Award" in my final year, and I made sure it was plastered all over my CV!

unnormalised: In fact, even the seemingly small things can make a difference. Did you volunteer for a cause during your studies? Did you learn a new language? Did you take on a leadership role in a student organization? These experiences can show that you're a well-rounded individual with diverse interests and skills. I volunteered with the "CRY Foundation" while doing my "BA" and it taught me a lot about empathy and social responsibility.

unnormalised: So, the next time you’re updating your resume or LinkedIn profile, don't just focus on the degrees. Dig deeper. What are the stories behind those certificates? What did you actually achieve? Those details are what will truly make you stand out from the crowd. It’s not just about having the piece of paper, it’s about what you did with it.
